text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion states that the response incorrectly advises that a constructive trust interest automatically has priority over a registered charge, and the ground truth is that a registered charge almost always has priority unless the interest is overriding or the charge is set aside. The candidate answer explicitly states the opposite of the incorrect advice described in the criterion. In Section 1, the candidate states: \"The mortgage is a **real right** that attaches to the *legal* title. Once the mortgage is **registered**, it becomes a **priority lien** that \u201cruns with the land\u201d and is enforceable against anyone who later acquires an interest, even an equitable one.\" It further concludes: \"If the \u20ac200\u202fk mortgage was **properly executed and registered**, the bank will, in most jurisdictions, be able to **realise its debt first**.\" This directly aligns with the ground truth that the registered charge has priority over a later equitable claim (like a constructive trust). Therefore, the candidate answer does *not* incorrectly advise that the constructive trust automatically has priority; it correctly advises the opposite.", "criterion_id": "efe892e8-3336-4d58-afc7-6400db760a08"}
